oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Application of carbon nanomaterial as a microwave absorber
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: SHARON, M
PRADHAN, D
ZACHARIA, R
PURI, V
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: shielding effectiveness
natural source
composites
films
camphor
fibers
microwave absorption
camphor cnt
carbon nanobeads from camphor
cnt microwave absorption
cvd
taguchi analysis
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Microwave absorption (8 GHz to 12 GHz) studies have been made with carbon nanomaterials for the first time. Carbon nanomaterials are synthesized by the pyrolysis of camphor. It is observed that film of carbon prepared under certain synthetic condition, can absorb microwave of either some specific wavelengths e.g., 9.5 GHz and 11.5 GHz or full range from 8-12 GHz to the extent of 20 dB depending upon their preparation condition. Carbon nanobeads seems to absorb the microwave in the range of 8-12 GHz.
